data.value: Perform Page's Test, a measure of trend in observations between treatments.
Page's Test (also known as Page's
test) is useful when:
* there are
treatments, *
subjects are observed for each treatment, and * the observations are hypothesized to have a particular order.
Specifically, the test considers the null hypothesis that
m_1 = m_2 = m_3 \cdots = m_n,
where
is the mean of the observed quantity under treatment
, against the alternative hypothesis that
m_1 \leq m_2 \leq m_3 \leq \cdots \leq m_n,
where at least one inequality is strict.
As noted by [4]_, Page's

test has greater statistical power than the Friedman test against the alternative that there is a difference in trend, as Friedman's test only considers a difference in the means of the observations without considering their order. Whereas Spearman
considers the correlation between the ranked observations of two variables (e.g. the airspeed velocity of a swallow vs. the weight of the coconut it carries), Page's

is concerned with a trend in an observation (e.g. the airspeed velocity of a swallow) across several distinct treatments (e.g. carrying each of five coconuts of different weight) even as the observation is repeated with multiple subjects (e.g. one European swallow and one African swallow).
A
array; the element in row
and column
is the observation corresponding with subject
and treatment
. By default, the columns are assumed to be arranged in order of increasing predicted mean.
By default,
is assumed to be observations rather than ranks; it will be ranked with
along

is provided in the form of ranks, pass argument

achieve reasonably accurate results in reasonable time (default)

_lines._line: * 'asymptotic': compares the standardized test statistic against

data.value: * 'asymptotic': compares the standardized test statistic against

_lines._line: * 'exact': computes the exact *p*-value by comparing the observed
:math:`L` statistic against those realized by all possible
permutations of ranks (under the null hypothesis that each

data.value: * 'exact': computes the exact *p*-value by comparing the observed
statistic against those realized by all possible permutations of ranks (under the null hypothesis that each permutation is equally likely)
An object containing attributes:
statistic : float
Page's
test statistic.
pvalue : float
The associated *p*-value

_lines._line: The method used to compute the *p*-value

data.value: method : {'asymptotic', 'exact'}
The method used to compute the *p*-value
As noted in [1]_, "the
'treatments' could just as well represent
objects or events or performances or persons or trials ranked." Similarly, the
'subjects' could equally stand for
"groupings by ability or some other control variable, or judges doing the ranking, or random replications of some other sort."
The procedure for calculating the
statistic, adapted from [1]_, is:

_lines._line: 1. "Predetermine with careful logic the appropriate hypotheses
concerning the predicted ording of the experimental results.
If no reasonable basis for ordering any treatments is known, the

data.value: 1. "Predetermine with careful logic the appropriate hypotheses
concerning the predicted ording of the experimental results. If no reasonable basis for ordering any treatments is known, the
test is not appropriate."

_lines._line: 2. "As in other experiments, determine at what level of confidence
you will reject the null hypothesis that there is no agreement of
experimental results with the monotonic hypothesis."

data.value: 2. "As in other experiments, determine at what level of confidence
you will reject the null hypothesis that there is no agreement of experimental results with the monotonic hypothesis."
3. "Cast the experimental material into a two-way table of
columns (treatments, objects ranked, conditions) and
rows (subjects, replication groups, levels of control variables)."

_lines._line: 4. "When experimental observations are recorded, rank them across each

data.value: 4. "When experimental observations are recorded, rank them across each
row", e.g.

_lines._line: 5. "Add the ranks in each column", e.g.

data.value: 5. "Add the ranks in each column", e.g.

_lines._line: 6. "Multiply each sum of ranks by the predicted rank for that same

data.value: 6. "Multiply each sum of ranks by the predicted rank for that same
column", e.g.
7. "Sum all such products", e.g.
[1]_ continues by suggesting use of the standardized statistic
"which is distributed approximately as chi-square with 1 degree of freedom. The ordinary use of

tables would be equivalent to a two-sided test of agreement. If a one-sided test is desired, *as will almost always be the case*, the probability discovered in the chi-square table should be *halved*."

However, this standardized statistic does not distinguish between the observed values being well correlated with the predicted ranks and being _anti_-correlated with the predicted ranks. Instead, we follow [2]_ and calculate the standardized statistic
\Lambda = \frac{L - E_0}{\sqrt{V_0}},
where
and
, "which is asymptotically normal under the null hypothesis".
The *p*-value for
is generated by comparing the observed value of
against the
values generated for all
possible permutations of ranks. The calculation is performed using the recursive method of [5].
The *p*-values are not adjusted for the possibility of ties. When ties are present, the reported
*p*-values may be somewhat larger (i.e. more conservative) than the true *p*-value [2]_. The
` *p*-values, however, tend to be smaller (i.e. less conservative) than the
*p*-values.

We use the example from [3]_: 10 students are asked to rate three teaching methods - tutorial, lecture, and seminar - on a scale of 1-5, with 1 being the lowest and 5 being the highest. We have decided that a confidence level of 99% is required to reject the null hypothesis in favor of our alternative: that the seminar will have the highest ratings and the tutorial will have the lowest. Initially, the data have been tabulated with each row representing an individual student's ratings of the three methods in the following order: tutorial, lecture, seminar.

Because the tutorial is hypothesized to have the lowest ratings, the column corresponding with tutorial rankings should be first; the seminar is hypothesized to have the highest ratings, so its column should be last. Since the columns are already arranged in this order of increasing predicted mean, we can pass the table directly into
This *p*-value indicates that there is a 0.1819% chance that the

statistic would reach such an extreme value under the null hypothesis. Because 0.1819% is less than 1%, we have evidence to reject the null hypothesis in favor of our alternative at a 99% confidence level.
The value of the
statistic is 133.5. To check this manually, we rank the data such that high scores correspond with high ranks, settling ties with an average rank:
We add the ranks within each column, multiply the sums by the predicted ranks, and sum the products.
